We’ve built our business around the belief that data-driven decisions are better decisions, and we’ve made it our mission to inspire and empower data driven people. In fact, sometimes data can do more harm than good.

lead_paragraph: State and federal authorities announced a criminal case against BNP Paribas on Monday for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States. BNP’s agreement to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty ends months of arm-twisting by French officials. It is also the culmination of a long investigation into some of the world’s top banks, which began with a bus bombing two decades ago and a grieving New Jersey father’s quest for justice, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write in DealBook.

abstract: New research suggests that overseas companies pay bigger fines and plead guilty more often than American ones do in United States prosecutions, Reynolds Holding writes for Reuters Breakingviews.

abstract: A collaboration between Dick Shlakman and Jeff Chen that makes headlines.
snippet: A collaboration between Dick Shlakman and Jeff Chen that makes headlines.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Dick Shlakman and Jeff Chen are back after Mr. Chen ably assisted Mr. Shlakman in his New York Times debut in February. At the time, Mr. Shlakman modestly admitted that Mr. Chen had done the lion’s share of the work and, indeed, Mr. Chen’s name was first in the byline. This time around, however, Mr. Shlakman’s name is first, and it makes me wonder if that’s a sign that he’s acquiring the constructing skills needed to eventually publish under a solo byline. That would be great, because then I could finally use the headline “Shlak’s Blocks Rock Socks.”

headline.main: Printed Points of View

lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, said on Tuesday in a note to the bank’s employees and shareholders that he had throat cancer and would begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, DealBook’s Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes. Doctors discovered the cancer at an early stage, Mr. Dimon said, noting that his condition was “curable.” Moreover, he said doctors had confirmed that the cancer had not spread beyond the “original site” and the adjacent lymph nodes on the right side of his neck. He described the prognosis from the doctors as “excellent.”

lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton, who assumed the lead when his teammate, Nico Rosberg, dropped out on the 47th lap, took the victory Sunday in the British Grand Prix at Silverstone. The win, coupled with Rosberg’s no-points nonfinish, helped Hamilton close to within four points of his teammate in the season’s driving championship. Rosberg, whose Mercedes had a gearbox failure, had been leading by 29 points entering the race; he had finished every previous grand prix this season.

lead_paragraph: Since the government’s crackdown on insider trading in the hedge fund industry became public in 2009 with the arrest of Raj Rajaratnam, federal prosecutors under Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, had secured 85 insider trading convictions and guilty pleas without one defeat. But on Tuesday, that perfect streak came to an end, Matthew Goldstein, Rachel Abrams and Ben Protess write in DealBook. After just under four hours of deliberation, a federal jury found Rengan Rajaratnam ‒ the younger brother of Raj Rajaratnam, who was convicted of insider trading in 2011 ‒ not guilty of conspiracy to commit insider trading with his older brother.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Prosecutors’ Perfect Streak Ends

abstract: The case of Deeb Salem, a former Goldman Sachs trader, highlights an arbitration system that is weighted toward the big Wall Street firms, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
snippet: The case of Deeb Salem, a former Goldman Sachs trader, highlights an arbitration system that is weighted toward the big Wall Street firms, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: Deeb Salem, the former Goldman Sachs trader who helped devise the firm’s brilliant and highly profitable proprietary bet against the mortgage market, has never been shy about trumpeting his accomplishments. Mr. Salem no longer works at Goldman — he decamped to GoldenTree Asset Management, a New York hedge fund, in 2012 — but his continuing lawsuit, which contends the firm shortchanged him about $21 million in bonus and deferred compensation during the years after the financial crisis, raises fresh questions about the fairness of Wall Street’s compensation practices, its willingness to make scapegoats out of former employees and the arbitration system — run by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority — that everyone who deals with Wall Street is forced to use to resolve monetary disputes.

headline.main: ‘Big Short’ Case Raises Questions About Finra Arbitration

Gitner, the 43-year-old defense lawyer who finally spoiled Preet Bharara’s perfect record in hedge fund insider trading cases, is nothing if not thorough, Rachel Abrams writes in DealBook. lead_paragraph: For the last two years, the City College of San Francisco has operated in the shadow of imminent death. It is the city’s main community college, with 77,000 students, and in June 2012 its accreditor warned that chronic financial and organizational mismanagement threatened its future. If the problems weren’t fixed in short order, the accreditor said, it would shut down the college. A year later, the accreditor decided that City College’s remedial efforts were too little, too late, and ordered the campus to close its doors this July.

abstract: Citigroup and the Justice Department agree to a $7 billion mortgage settlement. | AbbVie raised its bid for the Irish drug maker Shire. | Lindt to acquire Russell Stover Candies. | Companies that offer help with student loans are under scrutiny.
snippet: Citigroup and the Justice Department agree to a $7 billion mortgage settlement. | AbbVie raised its bid for the Irish drug maker Shire. | Lindt to acquire Russell Stover Candies. | Companies that offer help with student loans are under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup and the Justice Department have agreed to a $7 billion deal that will settle a federal investigation into the mortgage securities the bank sold in the run-up to the financial crisis, Michael Corkery writes in DealBook. The deal, announced on Monday morning, includes a $4 billion cash penalty to the Justice Department ‒ the largest payment of its kind ‒ as well as $2.5 billion in so-called soft dollars earmarked for aiding struggling consumers and $500 million to state attorneys general and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The bank, which is scheduled to announce second-quarter earnings at 8 a.m., said the settlement would result in a pretax charge of $3.8 billion before taxes in the period.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Citigroup in $7 Billion Settlement

lead_paragraph: I JOINED my family’s company, Banfi Vintners, in 1993 after I graduated from Georgetown. We’re wine importers based in Old Brookville, Long Island. My first job with the company was in marketing and events so I traveled around the country to meet with sales teams. Now one of my main responsibilities as a co-C.E.O. is managing our operations in Italy. I still do a lot of events since I’m responsible for getting our message out to the public. Wine is very personal, rooted in history, culture and romance. When people choose a wine, it’s based on more than price and packaging. There has to be a connection, and that’s my job.

The combined market value of the No. 2 and No. 3 cigarette makers in the United States has jumped more than $10 billion since merger talk surfaced. lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch has one last big takeover left in him. Time Warner makes the perfect swan song for the 83-year-old media mogul. The HBO-to-Looney Tunes conglomerate sits at the top of a pyramid where content is king, has no controlling shareholder and poses few insurmountable antitrust hurdles for 21st Century Fox. But winning will not just be a matter of price.

On Wednesday, Mr. Murdoch’s boldest bid yet emerged: an $80 billion takeover offer for Time Warner Inc., which would be the biggest media deal in more than a decade. Time Warner has rebuffed his offer and no talks are underway. lead_paragraph: The CIT Group, the lender to small and midsize businesses run by John A. Thain, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire the parent company of OneWest Bank for $3.4 billion in cash and stock, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The deal will bolster CIT’s lending abilities by more than doubling its deposit base. OneWest currently manages $15 billion in deposits, as well as $23 billion in assets, including commercial and home mortgages. It will merge with CIT’s own bank, creating a subsidiary with $28 billion in deposits and $67 billion in assets.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: CIT in Deal for OneWest

lead_paragraph: Time Warner shareholders who are pondering whether to surrender to Rupert Murdoch would be well advised to listen to the media mogul’s muzzled minorities. Most 21st Century Fox believers are relegated to owning nonvoting stock in the conglomerate, the same second-tier paper on offer as part of the $80 billion takeover bid for the owner of HBO, CNN and Warner Bros. studios. Griffin and his wife, Anne Dias Griffin, were a financial powerhouse, two hedge fund managers who captivated the Chicago social scene, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. But on Wednesday, Mr. Griffin, the head of the $20 billion investment firm Citadel, filed a divorce petition in Cook County, Ill., citing “irreconcilable differences” after 11 years of marriage. abstract: The use of digital patient records has not led to overbilling, as feared, according to a new report — but it has not yet delivered efficiency gains or improved care, either.
snippet: The use of digital patient records has not led to overbilling, as feared, according to a new report — but it has not yet delivered efficiency gains or improved care, either.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the financial crisis hit, the Obama administration decided to toss into the economic stimulus package a carrot to accelerate the computerization of health care. Within the roughly $800 billion pump-priming project, the health technology initiative could be seen as a modest down payment on the future: about $20 billion in incentives spread over several years to encourage doctors and hospitals to move from paper records into the computer age. The Bush administration had championed the cause, and, seizing a crisis-created opportunity, the Obama administration put up the money.

headline.main: The Lessons Thus Far From the Transition to Digital Patient Records

Although the Slingshot is not an automobile – it does not have air bags and does not meet federal motor vehicle safety standards – Polaris describes a ride that’s a lot like that of a sports car. The chief difference between the Slingshot and a typical two-seat sports car is the layout: two wheels in front and one in the back. lead_paragraph: Quick, who’s the chief executive of MetLife? That the name Steve Kandarian doesn’t roll off the tongue for almost anyone who isn’t deeply steeped in the insurance business is probably a good thing for MetLife’s shareholders. Better to speak softly, and keep his relative anonymity intact.

abstract: “How do you make shredding metal fun?” a chief executive asked. “For goodness’ sake, we are an industrial recycling plant.”
snippet: “How do you make shredding metal fun?” a chief executive asked. “For goodness’ sake, we are an industrial recycling plant.”
lead_paragraph: You know something that is often overlooked in business? Having fun at work. No, I am not talking about the make-believe fun of team-building exercises and paintball scrimmages and company picnics. Most of that is a waste of time. I’m talking about making the actual work fun so people take pleasure in doing it.

headline.main: Making Work Fun Is Not About Table Tennis and Paintball

lead_paragraph: A couple of home-grown tax breaks in the United States are making inversions look like a diversion. The American authorities are letting Windstream designate its telecommunications cables as real estate, qualifying them for tax breaks. And a partnership will shield assets of the energy firm Hess from the Internal Revenue Service.
